title: Question 76

children: A 58-year-old man is evaluated for disabling rhythmic movements involving his upper extremities. These movements started 8 years ago and now interfere with his job as a chemist. He reports that his handwriting has become illegible. Previous treatment with propranolol, primidone, and clonazepam did not improve these symptoms. He also has a history of kidney stones. Family history includes tremor in his brother and Parkinson disease in his uncle. He takes no medications.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. The patient's voice quivers during prolonged vowels. Bilateral upper extremities exhibit a high-amplitude rhythmic movement during the finger-to-nose task and with outstretched position. There are no involuntary movements when hands are placed on the chair arms. Rapid alternative movements, tone, and gait are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
First-line pharmacologic treatments for essential tremor include propranolol, primidone, and topiramate.
Surgical therapies, including deep-brain stimulation and focused ultrasound thalamotomy, can control tremor in refractory essential tremor associated with functional disability.
The most appropriate treatment is deep-brain stimulation (
Option B

). This patient has severe medication-refractory essential tremor. Essential tremor is the most common movement disorder, affecting 1% to 2% of the population. It is defined as an isolated tremor syndrome of at least 3 years' duration characterized by action tremor in the upper extremities, with or without involvement of other body parts, such as the head, larynx, or lower limbs. A family history of tremor is present in 50% of patients. First-line treatment for essential tremor includes propranolol, primidone, and topiramate. Clonazepam is a second-line treatment. In this patient, propranolol, primidone, and clonazepam have already proved ineffective, and topiramate (
Option E

) is contraindicated because of his history of kidney stones. Surgical therapies, including deep-brain stimulation (unilateral or bilateral) and focused ultrasound thalamotomy (only unilateral), can control tremor in refractory essential tremor associated with functional disability. Results of a randomized trial suggest that deep-brain stimulation results in greater functional improvements than thalamotomy and fewer adverse events, such as dysarthria, sensory disturbances, and gait disturbances.
Botulinum toxin injection (
Option A

) can be considered for management of essential tremor of the head and vocal cord, but its benefit for limb tremor is limited by the common adverse effect of local weakness. In addition, this treatment is not FDA-approved for treatment of tremor.
Levodopa (
Option C

) can be beneficial for resting tremor associated with parkinsonism. Tremor in Parkinson disease is asymmetric and associated with increased tone and bradykinesia. A large-amplitude bilateral action tremor, as seen in this patient, is inconsistent with Parkinson disease.
Occupational therapy (
Option D

) can help patients with mild essential tremor through adaptive strategies, such as weighted utensils and wrist weights. However, these strategies are often ineffective against severe high-amplitude tremor.

references: Haubenberger D, Hallett M. Essential tremor. N Engl J Med. 2018;378:1802-10.
